meanings.def: to bend or turn something into a particular shape
examples: Twist the wire to form a circle.
Her hair was twisted into a knot on top of her head.

meanings.def: to bend or turn something into a shape or position that is not normal or natural; to be bent or turned in this way
examples: twist something (+ adv./prep.) He grabbed me and twisted my arm behind my back.
+ adv./prep. Her face twisted in anger.
Her mouth was twisted out of shape by grief.
His mouth twisted bitterly.
My stomach twisted into knots.
Nicola's face twisted into a grimace of disgust.
The bike was just a heap of twisted metal.
The boy's leg was twisted back painfully.

meanings.def: to turn part of your body around while the rest stays still
examples: twist something (+ adv./prep.) He twisted his head around to look at her.
+ adv./prep. She twisted in her chair when I called her name.
Hold your arms out to the sides and twist your upper body.
He twisted sideways to face her.
Tim twisted round and glared at her.

meanings.def: to turn your body with quick, sharp movements and change direction often
examples: I twisted and turned to avoid being caught.
+ adv./prep. She tried unsuccessfully to twist free.
twist something/yourself + adv./prep. He managed to twist himself round in the restricted space.
She fired again and saw the creature twist violently.
Rachel twisted and turned in her sleep.
The prisoner twisted in his seat, trying to free the ropes around his wrists.

meanings.def: to turn something around in a circle with your hand
examples: Twist the knob to the left to open the door.
Nervously I twisted the ring on my finger.
She placed her hand on the doorknob and twisted slowly.
Try twisting the handle to the right.

meanings.def: to bend and change direction often
examples: The road twists and turns along the coast.
narrow twisting streets
a twisting staircase

meanings.def: to injure part of your body, especially your ankle, wrist or knee, bending it in an uncomfortable way
examples: She fell and twisted her ankle.

meanings.def: to wind something around or through an object
examples: She twisted a scarf around her head.
I twisted the bandage around his leg.
The telephone cable has got twisted (= wound around itself).

meanings.def: to move or grow by winding around something
examples: A snake was twisting around his arm.

meanings.def: to deliberately change the meaning of what somebody has said, or to present facts in a particular way, in order to benefit yourself or harm somebody else
examples: You always twist everything I say.
The newspaper was accused of twisting the facts.

meanings.def: to turn or wind strings, etc. together to make something longer or thicker
examples: They had twisted the sheets into a rope and escaped by climbing down it.

meanings.def: to say or do something unkind deliberately; to make somebody who is unhappy feel even more unhappy
examples: Marcia laughed as she twisted the knife still deeper.
Just to twist the knife, the filmmakers have provided a surprise ending.

meanings.def: to persuade or force somebody to do something
to persuade somebody to do anything that you want
examples: She has always been able to twist her parents around her little finger.

idioms.def: to say or do something unkind deliberately; to make somebody who is unhappy feel even more unhappy
examples: Marcia laughed as she twisted the knife still deeper.
Just to twist the knife, the filmmakers have provided a surprise ending.

idioms.def: to persuade or force somebody to do something

idioms.idiom: twist/wrap/wind somebody around your little finger
idioms.def: to persuade somebody to do anything that you want
examples: She has always been able to twist her parents around her little finger.

related: get your knickers in a twist

meanings.def: the action of turning something with your hand, or of turning a part of your body
examples: She gave the lid another twist and it came off.
He gave a shy smile and a little twist of his head.
He finished him off with a quick twist of the knife.

meanings.def: an unexpected change or development in a story or situation
examples: the twists and turns of his political career
The story has taken another twist.
The disappearance of a vital witness added a new twist to the case.
By a curious twist of fate we met again only a week or so later.
a bizarre twist to the tale
The writer takes well-known fairy tales and gives them an ironic twist.
In a bizarre twist to the evening the police came at eleven and arrested our host.
The movie gives this old legend a real modern twist.
the latest twist in the saga of high-level corruption
horror movies with twist endings
I thought it would be an interesting twist on the zombie movie.
I added my own twist to the whole thing.
classic French dishes with a twist

meanings.def: a sharp bend in a road or river
examples: The car followed the twists and turns of the mountain road.
They approached a twist in the path.

meanings.def: a thing that has been twisted into a particular shape
examples: mineral water with a twist of lemon
A twist in the hose was stopping the water coming out.
a wry twist to her lips

meanings.def: a fast dance that was popular in the 1960s, in which you twist from side to side
to become angry, confused or upset
crazy
examples: She's gone completely round the twist.
